title: September 29
description:
Felix is feeling more grown up as he habituates to middle school.
  • He bikes home from school by himself or with friends. Without a parent!
  • He has friends calling to "hang out": the era of the "playdate" is well and truly bygone.
  • He goes to all-day weekend activities without us, like playing Dungeons & Dragons at the local comic book store.

There's also a touch of the "I said I was coming down for supper" teen-ness. But it's very slight: he's still a lovable cuddly loving thing. Not like many pre-teens we know. Let's call it pre-teen pre-attitude.

children.title: Wheels of Misfortune
children.description:
Lucie returned to a wheelless bike after yoga class this last Sunday. What a sad sight. Lesson learned: one must lock bike wheels in this town.

The faint silver lining is that it was a 12 year old bike, getting worn down in all its parts. She opted to get a new bike. She's always wanted a red bike. The new one's coming with locking wheel hubs and seat post.

children.title: Biker Gang
children.description:
Lucie and the kids bike to school most days.

Lucie currently has a gig in Oakland and bikes on to work after dropping off the kids. She's using Dean's bike here, while her new bike is on order.

Both Felix and Milo have graduated to the next bike size up. They're such strong bikers now that Lucie doesn't need to slow down at all. In fact, she sometimes has to go faster to catch up!

children.title: First Dance
children.description:
A rite of passage in America: the middle school dance!

This is Felix, Parker and Adriana in various states of deck-outedness. Or not.

Felix gave it a slightly-tipped-sideway thumbs up. He had a good time jumping around to the music with his friends for a while, but he wished there had been other things to do beside dancing and eating chips.

children.title: Kiril
children.description:
Once a year our dojo organizes West Coast Training Camp.

It's the not-to-be-missed event for all Cuong Nhu students near and far. Most of the grandmasters in the US come. Attendees trek in from Seattle, Washington DC, Atlanta, Florida and further afield.

Milo is practicing tonfa techniques with Kiril, who happens to also be a fourth grader at Ecole Bilingue

children.title: Andrei
children.description: Kiril's brother Andrei is in Felix's class.

children.title: Nicki
children.description:
Tonfas are martial art weapons. Everyone who takes the tonfa class at West Coast Training Camp gets a free tonfa.

Felix and Nicki take a swing with their new possessions.

Nicki doesn't go to Ecole Bilingue but the kids have become good friends from practicing karate together for years. That's one of the best part about our dojo. It fosters a real sense of community among the students.

children.title: Adriana
children.description: Adriana is yet another Cuong Nhu student who also happens to go to our school. She asked all the senseis to sign her tonfa.

children.title: Karate Family
children.description: The mighty Moses tonfa salute!

children.title: Cody
children.description: And here comes Cody, another fourth-grader from EB. Milo and Cody are on the same soccer team.

children.title: Alicia
children.description: Hi Alicia!

children.title: Patrick
children.description:
Patrick and daughter Sidney joined the dojo a few months ago and they are loving it so much they convinced the rest of the family to join. Sydney's little sister Samantha goes to the Tiger Team and mom Kim just started as well.

Lucie and Patrick often practice together during Parents' Class.

children.title: Jim
children.description: Cody's dad Jim is not really a Cuong Nhu student but he has a black belt in shotokan karate so he joined the fun for West Coast Training Camp.

children.title: Grandmaster
children.description:
Grandmaster Quynh Ngo is the official head of the Cuong Nhu martial art. He has the highest ranking belt of them all. He lives in Jacksonville, Florida. He's the son of Grandmaster Ngo Dong, the man who created Cuong Nhu in Vietnam in the 60's and brought it to the United States in the 70's.

What a honor for Felix to be chosen as his assistant for his knife defense demonstration!

children.title: Knife
children.description: Don't worry, Grandmaster Quynh Ngo did not stab Felix with a real knife. It was made of balsa wood.

children.title: Tournament
children.description:
After all the kids practice knife defense blocks for about an hour, Grandmaster Quynh Ngo organized an informal tournament.

The kids demonstrated their skills in pairs until only the best two remained: Felix vs. Felix!

children.title: Double Felix
children.description:
You've heard about the double helix but did you know about the double Felix?

This other Felix is about a year older than our Felix. Both Felixes go to Rohai Dojo.

children.title: Winner
children.description:
After many rounds of eliminations, Grandmaster Quynh Ngo made his choice. At the end of the day, when everyone was bowing out, he announced the 2013 Knife Champion...

Felix Moses!

What a proud moment!

Everyone clapped and Lucie woohooed with the most un-martial-art-like exuberance.

children.title: Cuong Nhu ❤
children.description: We ❤ Cuong Nhu!

children.title: Ulysses
children.description:
Birthday Party for Ulysses at San Luis Park.

Happy Birthday Ulysses! You're getting so tall.

children.title: Boy Tree
children.description: Count them: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 boys in a tree.

children.title: First Laptop
children.description:
Another rite of passage: Felix's first laptop!

The school issues each student a laptop to use for their three years there. Afterwards they get to keep it.

Homework assignments are all delivered via laptop.

We had been concerned about him having always-available access to games, but so far the computer been an unabashed good thing. The kids aren't allowed to install games, and many game websites are blocked. The computer gets used for schoolwork and doing fun quasi-educational stuff at home, like recording music tracks in Garage Band or producing little animated movies with programs like Styxz.
